blog.description: President Obama will soon be sworn into office, and whether you voted for him or not, he's everybody's president. What do you want him to remember in his second term? We will feature your responses in our inauguration coverage!
blog.title: Dear Mr. President
blog.name: inauguration2013

posts.caption:
Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

Please keep religious influence out of our laws and funding decisions. Women deserve the right to affordable and accessible healthcare, and gay couples deserve the right to legal marriage. If religious organizations can influence politics, they should at least pay taxes to to do so.

Please pay more attention and funding to mental health research and treatment. While I support gun control laws, bare in mind that criminals don’t care about gun laws. However, I can’t help but wonder how many tragedies may have been prevented, had the perpetrators received proper psychological treatment.

Please reduce corporate influence in laws regarding food and medicine. Pharmaceutical companies create more customers than cures, and we deserve to know whether our food is safe/healthy.

Please help our planet, our home. Stop letting greedy corporations destroy it. Tighten environmental laws, and pay attention to climate change issues. They are real!

You promised us change. I know it can’t happen quickly, and that it’s mostly due to republicans sabotaging whatever you present to them, but enough is enough! Find a way to overcome the naysayers that stand between us and progress toward a healthier country.

Signed,
Kristin Young from San Diego, California

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

It turns out getting things done as President isn’t as easy as it seems it would be. The first four years of your Presidency weren’t as impactful as you told us they would be— as you believed they would be— I’m sure you’re as disappointed in this as anyone.

They say we’re the country of second chances so here’s yours. The politics are over now. If you want to leave a legacy you have some catching up to do but the American people, myself included, think you’re up for the challenge. Make the right decisions, not the political ones. Reach across the aisle to get things done. When in doubt, trust your gut because that’s how you became the President of the United States of America.

Signed,
Trevor from Durham, NC

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

Dear Chief Executive Obama,

While you take time these next few years resting in the Executive Mansion, please remember that you made a promise not only to the American people but to our brothers and sisters in Puerto Rico to follow up on the November 2012 plebiscite. They voted for a change in status and that if the status were to change a great majority supported “STATEHOOD.” Please end the undue second-class treatment of US citizens living in a US commonwealth. Push for the 51st State,

Signed,
Cliff Weyrauch from Gainesville, FL

Dear Mr. President,

I’d rather not say how I voted.

Signed,
from

Dear Mr. President,

I’d rather not say how I voted.

Everyone matters, Mr. President.

Signed,
Colleen from Detroit, Mi

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

Dear viewers and Mr. President
I am not black, I am not rich, and I am not gay. So why should you hear what I have to say? Well I love this country and the way things have been going on in the past 4+ years is just troubling. Where does the buck stop? I am talking to you and people who think it is all going great. Why must you always attack people who work hard for their money and make enough to be comfortable? Why must you and your party belittle women into thinking they have no rights, I spent 3 weeks in Africa, all of you should go there and see how those people have no rights! Why is it that you Mr. President are always blaming congress and the senate, your administration, and the states…take some responsibility!
The fact is that people want to see you do good things and want you to succeed. But how can they when me and my friends were promised no tax changes, and when our checks came in the mail this past week my pay showed $100 less? Or why my entire departments hours were cut last month because of ‘No ObamaCare expenses’.
Although I am Christian Italian it bothers me to see the way you treat Israel, it is one stab in the back after the next (don’t shrub, you know I’m right people).
Lastly, I lost friends and 2 cousins on 9/11, so if I here one more idiot say how Bush ran us into a war about oil and it was all on a credit card, I want you to think if that was YOUR child! or Sibling! Or parent! That died in that building… You would shut the hell up and demand them to be avenged by these radical terrorist that want nothing more than YOU dead (whom Obama went to during his trip to the Middle East and apologized for the air that you breath).

Signed,
Jake from Bronx, NY

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

I did not vote for you simply because I do no agree with the directions your policies have taken. You have continued the slaughter of innocent civilians in the Middle East while preaching gun control in the wake of tragedy. You have let Wall Street continue to run roughshod over this country with minimal regulations. You have continued funding and even doubled down on the War on Drugs which has ruined the lives of many innocent people in this country who are doing no harm to the people around them. You have opened up three times as much land to oil and gas drilling as you have protected from such activities. As a liberal voter, I wanted to vote for you until I read up on the things you have done to ruin the lives of other Americans. You have four years to correct this legacy and be remembered as a force for good; a true symbol of “hope” and “change we can believe in.” I would love to see the return of the liberal I loved back in 2008 and I would love to see you improve as we expect all Americans to improve.

Signed,
Kris Smoot from Frankfort, KY

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote.

The U.S. nuclear arsenall budget costs more per year than the Millenium Development Goals would take TOTAL. All of this for weapons that we will never use. I want President Obama to continue to take the lead on working to remove these dangerous and costly weapons from the world.

Signed,
Cory from Columbia, SC

Dear Mr. President,

I’d rather not say how I voted.

Investing in high quality early childhood programs results in a higher rate of return according to many economists. “We contend that investing in early childhood development yields a much higher return than most government- funded economic development initiatives” (The Economics of Early Childhood Development, Rolnick and Grunewald 2007, p. 13). The future success of the country depends on the success, achievement and capacity of it’s future citizens…it starts at birth….

Signed,
Heather from Phoenix, AZ

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

We seem very concerned about American children being killed by assault weapons, but not at all concerned with children of other nations being killed by our drones, over and over again. This is shameful, and “we didn’t mean it” doesn’t excuse it. I voted for you both times, and this is a huge disappointment for me.

Signed,
Kathy O’Malley from Princeton, IL
